questions.text: The primary lymphoid organ is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thymus

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature. The primary lymphoid organs are where lymphocytes (B cells and T cells) are produced and mature. The thymus specifically is the site of T cell maturation, a crucial process for the development of the immune system.

 

The bone marrow is another primary lymphoid organ, where B cells mature.

 

Secondary lymphoid organs, in contrast, are sites where mature lymphocytes become activated in response to antigens. These include the lymph nodes, spleen, Peyer’s patches, and tonsils.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver: The liver is not considered a lymphoid organ. It plays a role in various metabolic processes, detoxification, and protein synthesis, but it is not involved in the direct maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They are involved in filtering lymph and providing a site for the interaction of lymphocytes with antigens, which helps initiate the immune response.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is also a secondary lymphoid organ. It filters blood, removes old red blood cells, and helps in the immune response by facilitating the interaction between lymphocytes and antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It plays a critical role in the development of the immune system.

choices.text: High levels of CMV IgG with high avidity
Presence of CMV IgM with low avidity IgG
High avidity IgG with negative IgM

questions.text: Which of the following is best serological marker of acute CMV infection in a pregnant woman? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Presence of CMV IgM with low avidity IgG

 

Explanation: 

 

In acute CMV infection, the presence of CMV IgM antibodies along with low avidity IgG is the most reliable indicator. Low avidity IgG indicates recent infection as antibodies haven't yet matured to high binding strength, which typically takes 2-4 months. When combined with positive IgM, this strongly suggests acute primary infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High levels of CMV IgG with high avidity: High avidity IgG indicates past infection, not acute infection, as antibodies have already matured to strong binding strength.

 

Option C. Presence of CMV IgG alone: CMV IgG alone only indicates past exposure to CMV and doesn't differentiate between acute or past infection.

 

Option D. High avidity IgG with negative IgM: This pattern typically indicates past infection with no current reactivation or acute infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of CMV IgM positivity and low avidity IgG provides the strongest evidence for acute primary CMV infection, which is particularly important in pregnant women due to risk of congenital transmission.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. It occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream causing an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis.

 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections are:

 

  • Food poisoning - caused by enterotoxin
  • Toxic shock syndrome- caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome- caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by the release of TSST-1 and other superantigens leading to severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliative toxins leading to the destruction of the skin's epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not mediated by toxins, unlike staphylococcal food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which are all toxin-mediated infections.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the causative agent associated with in this case? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pure red cell aplasia

 

  • The provided picture displays the typical appearance of a slapped cheek  due to cutaneous vasodilatation, indicating a probable case of erythema infectiosum.
  • This condition is caused by the Parvovirus B19.
  • Parvovirus B19 is linked to pure red cell aplasia.

 

MANIFESTATIONS OF PARVOVIRUS B19

 

1. Fetus

  • Severe anemia (transient aplastic crises)
  • Pure red cell aplasia
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Spontaneous abortion

 

 

2. Children/adults

  • Fifth disease, erythema infectiosum, slapped cheek fever
  • 7−10-day incubation
  • Nonspecific “flu-like” symptoms followed by raised, indurated facial rash (Slapped cheek)

 

 

3. Adults

  • Rash and arthralgias (involves wrist most often) are due to immune complexes in the skin and joints.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gingivostomatitisis can be caused by Herpes virus.

 

Option C. Molluscum contagiosum is an infection caused by a poxvirus 

 

Option D. Kaposi sarcoma is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19, the causative agent of erythema infectiosum, is associated with pure red cell aplasia, particularly in individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders.

questions.text: The structure indicated by the black circle in the electron micrograph represents? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Postsynaptic density

 

Explanation:

 

  • The arrow in the electron micrograph points to the postsynaptic density
  • This appears as an electron-dense thickening of the postsynaptic membrane
  • It contains receptors, ion channels, and scaffolding proteins essential for synaptic transmission
  • The postsynaptic density is a characteristic feature of chemical synapses

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria:

 

  • Mitochondria appear as oval or elongated structures with distinct double membranes
  • They contain visible cristae and a matrix
  • While present in the image, they are not what the arrow indicates

 

Option B. Golgi bodies:

 

  • Golgi apparatus appears as stacked, flattened membrane cisternae
  • Often surrounded by small vesicles
  • The structure pointed to lacks the characteristic stack-like appearance of Golgi

 

Option C. Synapse:

 

  • While this is a synaptic junction, the arrow specifically points to the postsynaptic density
  • The synapse includes both pre- and postsynaptic elements, synaptic cleft, and associated structures
  • This option is too general for the specific structure indicated

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Ultrastructural features of synapses
  2. Identification of specific synaptic components in electron micrographs
  3. Distinguishing between different cellular organelles
  4. The importance of postsynaptic density in synaptic function

choices.text: Primary response occurs mainly in bone marrow, secondary in lymph nodes
Primary response occurs in lymph nodes and spleen, secondary in bone marrow and lymph nodes
Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in bone marrow
Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in lymph nodes

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the location of immune responses? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primary response occurs in lymph nodes and spleen, secondary in bone marrow and lymph nodes

 

  • Primary response appears mainly in the lymph nodes and spleen
  • Secondary response appears mainly in the bone marrow, followed by the spleen and lymph nodes

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary response occurs mainly in bone marrow, secondary in lymph nodes: Incorrect because primary response does not mainly occur in bone marrow; it occurs primarily in lymph nodes and spleen.

 

Option C. Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in bone marrow: Incorrect because primary response does not occur mainly in bone marrow, and secondary response isn't limited to bone marrow alone.

 

Option D: Both primary and secondary responses occur mainly in lymph nodes: Incorrect because while lymph nodes are involved in both responses, it doesn't account for the bone marrow's significant role in secondary response and spleen's role in primary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding anatomical sites of immune responses
  • Primary response: lymph nodes and spleen are main sites
  • Secondary response: bone marrow is the primary site, followed by spleen and lymph nodes
  • Different anatomical locations reflect different cellular mechanisms involved in each response

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

questions.text: Epithelial lining of trachea is made of which type of cells? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudostratified ciliated columnar cells

 

The epithelial lining of the trachea consists of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. This type of epithelium appears to be layered (stratified) due to the varying positions of the nuclei within the cells, but in reality, all cells are attached to the basement membrane, making it a "pseudostratified" layer. The presence of cilia on the apical surface of the cells helps in the movement of mucus and trapped particles out of the respiratory tract, which is crucial for maintaining respiratory health.

 

 

 

Note - Kartagener Syndrome which is characterized by a triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and infertility. This syndrome is linked to defects in the ciliary structure and function, known as primary ciliary dyskinesia, affecting not just respiratory epithelium but also other ciliated cells in the body, such as those in the reproductive tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ciliated columnar cells: Although the cells are ciliated, they are not simply columnar; they are pseudostratified columnar cells.

 

Option B. Non-ciliated cuboidal cells: This type of epithelium is typically found in smaller ducts and glands, not in the respiratory tract, making it incorrect for the trachea.

 

Option D. Simple columnar cells: This type of epithelium is found in areas like the gastrointestinal tract, where absorption is a key function. It is not characteristic of the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trachea is lined with pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium, which plays a critical role in trapping and moving particles out of the respiratory system to keep the airways clear.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fimbriae

 

Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

 

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

 

Functions of pili:

 

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytoplasmic membrane: While important for many cellular functions, the cytoplasmic membrane itself is not typically involved in adhesion.

 

Option B. Mesosomes: These are folded invaginations in the bacterial membrane thought to be artifacts of cell preparation and not involved in adhesion.

 

Option D. Lipopolysaccharides (LPS): Found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, LPS can play a role in interactions with the host immune system but are not primarily responsible for adhesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fimbriae are essential bacterial structures for adhesion, enabling bacteria to attach to host cells and surfaces, crucial for initiating infections and forming biofilms. This key role makes them important targets for strategies to prevent and treat bacterial infections.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: A child who is regularly eating outside is presenting with icterus and diarrhea, which of the following infectious agent can spread through the Feco-oral route? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis A

 

Hepatitis A is a viral liver infection that spreads primarily through the feco-oral route, often through contaminated food and water. It is commonly associated with poor sanitation and overcrowded areas, making it prevalent in areas with inadequate food and water hygiene.

 

Key Points about Hepatitis A:

 

  • Transmission Route: Spread through the feco-oral route.
  • Symptoms: Can cause icterus (jaundice) and gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea.
  • Risk Factors: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with the virus, especially in areas with poor sanitation.
  • Prevention: Good hygiene practices, proper sanitation, and vaccination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Incorrect. Hepatitis B is primarily spread through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child during childbirth, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C: Incorrect. Hepatitis C is mainly transmitted through blood-to-blood contact, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D: Incorrect. Hepatitis D only occurs in those infected with Hepatitis B and is transmitted in the same ways as Hepatitis B, not through the feco-oral route.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A and Hepatitis E spread through the Feco-oral route

 

Transmission of Hepatitis B, C, and D can occur sexually

questions.text: Match the following? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

  • Malaria (A-4, Giemsa stain): Giemsa's solution is a mixture of methylene blue, eosin, and Azure B. It is used to stain blood smears for the identification of malarial parasites. Giemsa's stain is regarded as the world's standard diagnostic technique for malaria's plasmodium, and it is also the basic stain for classifying lymphomas in the Kiel classification.
  • Tuberculosis (B-1, ZN stain): The Ziehl-Neelsen method uses a carbol fuchsin stain, acid alcohol decolorizer, and methylene blue counterstain. Acid-fast organisms, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, stain red, while the background of debris stains blue. The ZN stain confirms the acid-fast property of mycobacteria.
  • Leprosy (C-2, Fite Faraco stain): Fite-Faraco stain is the routinely used method to demonstrate Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. It is more sensitive than the ZN method in the detection of Mycobacterium leprae in tissue sections. The leprosy bacillus is much less acid and alcohol fast than the tubercle bacillus, therefore alcohol is removed from the hydrating and dehydrating steps and 10% sulphuric acid is used as a decolorizer in place of acid/alcohol solution.

 

Mycobacterial cell walls contain a waxy substance composed of mycolic acids. These are ß-hydroxy carboxylic acids with chain lengths of up to 90 carbon atoms. The property of acid fastness is related to the carbon chain length of the mycolic acid found in any particular species.

 

  • Actinomycosis (D-3, Gram stain): Actinomyces species are gram-positive bacteria, and the Gram stain is used to visualize them. Actinomyces appear as filamentous, branching, gram-positive rods when stained with the Gram stain. Gram stain is more sensitive for the diagnosis of actinomycosis than culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each infectious disease has a specific staining technique for identification: Malaria (Giemsa stain), Tuberculosis (ZN stain), Leprosy (Fite Faraco stain), and Actinomycosis (Gram stain).

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presents with foot pain. On examination, you can easily palpate all foot pulses except for a particular artery. The image shows the correct technique for palpating this absent pulse. Which artery is being examined? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dorsalis pedis artery

 

Explanation:

 

In diabetic patients, the dorsalis pedis artery pulse is particularly important to assess as it can be one of the first pulses to become impalpable due to peripheral arterial disease. The dorsalis pedis artery is examined:

 

  • On the dorsum of the foot
  • Between the first and second metatarsals
  • Best palpated with patient's foot slightly dorsiflexed
  • Absence in up to 10% of normal population (anatomical variant)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior tibial artery:

 

  • Palpated posterior to medial malleolus
  • Usually remains palpable even in early peripheral vascular disease
  • More consistent anatomically than dorsalis pedis

 

Option C. Popliteal artery:

 

  • Palpated in popliteal fossa with knee flexed
  • Deep location makes it difficult to palpate normally
  • Not commonly affected in isolation in peripheral arterial disease

 

Option D. Perforating peroneal artery:

 

  • Not routinely palpated in clinical examination
  • Branch of peroneal artery
  • Too small for clinical pulse assessment

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Proper technique for dorsalis pedis pulse examination is crucial in:

  1. Assessing peripheral vascular disease
  2. Diabetic foot evaluation
  3. Pre-operative assessment

Differentiating between anatomical variation and pathological absence The dorsalis pedis pulse is particularly important in diabetic patients as its absence may be the first sign of peripheral arterial disease

questions.text: In the image shown below, what is the main function of the muscle marked in green (lateral pterygoid) during mandibular movement? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Protrusion

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lateral pterygoid's primary function is mandibular protrusion
  • Bilateral contraction moves mandible forward
  • Essential for grinding movements during mastication
  • Important in TMJ biomechanics

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Primarily function of masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid
  • Closes the jaw
  • Lateral pterygoid not involved in elevation
  • Important in biting and chewing

 

Option C. Depression:

 

  • Mainly performed by digastric, mylohyoid, and geniohyoid
  • Opens the mouth
  • Lateral pterygoid relaxes during depression
  • Gravity assists this movement

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Performed by posterior fibers of temporalis
  • Posterior digastric assists
  • Moves mandible posteriorly
  • Lateral pterygoid actually antagonizes this movement

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding muscles of mastication: 
    • Functions of individual muscles
    • Movement combinations
    • TMJ mechanics
    • Clinical relevance: 
      • TMJ disorders
      • Masticatory dysfunction
      • Bruxism
      • Facial pain syndromes

questions.text: A patient presented with an enlarged inguinal lymph node. Which of the following is the most likely primary cause? (NEET PG 2020 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anal cancer

 

Enlargement of the inguinal lymph node is most commonly caused by the anal canal below the dentate line (which marks the border between the anal canal and rectum) goes into the inguinal lymph nodes. As a result, anal cancer occurring below the dentate line can lead to the enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes.

 

However, lymphatics from the anal canal above the dentate line (i.e., the rectum) drain into the internal iliac lymph nodes through superior rectal lymphatics.

 

Anal Cancer:  A malignancy that originates in the anal canal or anal margin.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage from the anal canal is to the inguinal lymph nodes. Hence, an enlarged inguinal lymph node can indicate the spread of a tumor from the anal region.
  • Clinical Relevance: Patients with anal cancer may present with anal bleeding, pain, or itching. Inguinal lymph node enlargement is an important sign to check for, as it indicates lymphatic spread.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the testes.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the testes is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Therefore, testicular tumors typically spread first to these nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While testicular cancer can metastasize to the inguinal lymph nodes, it's an unusual pathway and typically occurs after a surgical procedure in the groin, which can disrupt the typical lymphatic drainage patterns.

 

Option C. Sigmoid Colon Cancer: Malignancy that arises from the sigmoid portion of the colon.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the sigmoid colon is to the colic nodes and then to the inferior mesenteric nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Inguinal lymph node enlargement is not a typical early site of metastasis for sigmoid colon cancer. More common metastatic sites include the liver and lungs.

 

Option D. Prostate Cancer: Malignancy that originates within the prostate gland.

 

  • Lymphatic Spread: The primary lymphatic drainage of the prostate is to the internal iliac lymph nodes and then to the external iliac nodes.
  • Clinical Relevance: While it's possible for prostate cancer to metastasize to the inguinal nodes, it's not the typical pattern of lymphatic spread. Symptoms of prostate cancer include urinary frequency, nocturia, and difficulty starting and maintaining a steady stream of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anal cancer is a primary malignancy associated with the enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes due to its anatomical and lymphatic relationship with the anal canal below the dentate line. Recognizing this link is crucial for correct diagnosis and treatment planning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pour plate culture

 

Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However, it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it's high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Screening Tests for UTI:

 

Option B. Griess Nitrite test: This test detects nitrites in the urine, which are generally produced by nitrate-reducing bacteria such as Escherichia coli, a common cause of UTIs. It is a quick and effective screening tool.

 

Option C. Leukocyte esterase test: This test identifies the presence of leukocyte esterase, an enzyme released by white blood cells (leukocytes). A positive result suggests inflammation or infection, common in UTIs.

 

Option D. Wet mount examination: This involves examining a sample of urine under a microscope to detect the presence of pus cells, bacteria, or other elements indicative of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

 

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine.
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

 

Quantitative Culture:

 

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: Identify the papillae of the tongue that serve a mechanical function but do not contribute to taste sensation. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Filiform

 

Filiform papillae are the most numerous papillae on the surface of the tongue. They are elongated, keratinized projections that cover the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. Unlike other papillae, filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. Their primary function is to provide a rough surface that aids in the mechanical aspect of chewing by creating an abrasive texture that helps manipulate food.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Circumvallate: These papillae are located near the back of the tongue in a V-shaped arrangement just in front of the sulcus terminalis. They contain taste buds on their lateral surfaces and are responsible for the perception of bitter tastes.

 

Option C. Foliate: Foliate papillae are located on the lateral edges of the tongue. They contain taste buds that are responsible for the perception of sour tastes, although they are less prominent in humans compared to some other animals.

 

Option D. Fungiform: These mushroom-shaped papillae are scattered across the tongue's surface, particularly near the tip and sides. They contain taste buds and are responsible for the perception of sweet, salty, and umami tastes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Four types of papillae on the tongue:

  1. Filiform
  2. Fungiform
  3. Circumvallate
  4. Foliate

 

Taste buds are barrel-shaped structures located in the epithelium of the foliate and fungiform papillae, as well as on the lateral sides of the circumvallate papillae.

 

Taste buds are absent in the filiform papillae, which are the most numerous and smallest papillae on the surface of the tongue. They cover the entire dorsal surface of the tongue.

questions.text: The membrane covering an omphalocele is primarily formed by which of the following embryonic structures? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

An omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines or other abdominal organs protrude outside of the body through the umbilical ring but are covered by a protective membrane. This membrane consists of multiple layers:

 

  • Inner Layer: The inner layer of the covering is the peritoneum, which lines the abdominal cavity.
  • Middle Layer: Wharton’s jelly, a gelatinous substance, is located between the peritoneum and the outer covering.
  • Outer Layer: The outermost layer of the covering is derived from the amnion, which is part of the fetal membrane surrounding the developing fetus.

 

Thus, the amnion forms the outermost layer covering the omphalocele, providing protection to the protruding organs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer that gives rise to internal structures like the lining of the gastrointestinal tract, not the covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, and connective tissues but does not specifically contribute to the external covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is another fetal membrane that participates in placental formation but does not directly form the covering of the omphalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The outer covering of an omphalocele is derived from the amnion, with the peritoneum lining the inner surface and Wharton’s jelly situated between the peritoenum and outer covering.

questions.text: The marked structure secretes which hormone? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adrenaline

 

The marked structure in the provided histological image is the adrenal medulla. The adrenal medulla is the innermost part of the adrenal gland and is responsible for the secretion of catecholamines, primarily adrenaline (epinephrine) and norepinephrine. These hormones are crucial for the "fight or flight" response, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and energy availability.

 

 

 

 

In the adrenal gland, there are three distinct zones in the cortex, each responsible for secreting different hormones:

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa (outermost): Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulate sodium and potassium balance.
  2. Zona fasciculata (middle): Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which are involved in glucose metabolism, immune response, and stress response.
  3. Zona reticularis (innermost cortex layer): Secretes androgens, which are sex hormones.

 

The adrenal medulla, which lies beneath these cortical layers, contains chromaffin cells that secrete adrenaline. This area is marked in the image, making adrenaline the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Androgen: Androgens are secreted by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option C. Glucocorticoid: Glucocorticoids, such as cortisol, are secreted by the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex.

 

Option D. Mineralocorticoid: Mineralocorticoids, such as aldosterone, are secreted by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal medulla, the innermost part of the adrenal gland, is responsible for secreting adrenaline, a hormone essential for the body's acute stress response.

questions.text: Corticospinal tract crosses the midline at: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lower medulla

 

The corticospinal tract is a major pathway that carries motor signals from the brain down to the spinal cord to control voluntary movements, particularly those involving the limbs. This tract originates in the cerebral cortex, descends through the brainstem, and continues into the spinal cord.

 

At the level of the lower medulla, the corticospinal tract fibers cross to the opposite side of the body in a process known as the pyramidal decussation. This crossing of the fibers is crucial as it means that each side of the brain controls the opposite side of the body. The pyramidal decussation marks the transition from the medulla oblongata to the spinal cord and is a key anatomical landmark in the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pons: The pons is a part of the brainstem situated above the medulla. While the corticospinal tract passes through the pons, it does not cross the midline here. The crossing, or decussation, occurs only in the lower medulla.

 

Option C. Middle medulla: While the corticospinal tract descends through the middle medulla, the actual crossing of the fibers (decussation) occurs further down in the lower medulla, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Midbrain: The corticospinal tract passes through the midbrain as it descends from the cortex, but no crossing occurs at this level. The pyramidal decussation occurs lower, at the level of the medulla.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corticospinal tract crosses the midline at the lower medulla in a process known as pyramidal decussation, which is essential for the control of voluntary movements by the opposite side of the brain.

questions.text: The marked structure (mammillary body) is a part of which anatomical circuit involved in memory formation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Papez circuit

 

Explanation:

 

The mammillary bodies are key components of the Papez circuit, which is crucial for memory formation and emotional processing. The Papez circuit follows this sequence:

  • Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Mammillothalamic tract → Anterior thalamic nucleus → Cingulate gyrus → Parahippocampal gyrus → Hippocampus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yakovlev circuit: This circuit is involved in emotional behavior and includes the orbitofrontal cortex, anterior temporal lobe, amygdala, and anterior insula. While it deals with emotion, it doesn't primarily involve the mammillary bodies.

 

Option C. Basal ganglia circuit: This circuit involves the striatum, globus pallidus, substantia nigra, and subthalamic nucleus. It's primarily involved in motor control and learning, not memory formation through mammillary bodies.

 

Option D. Meyers loop: This refers to the anterior loop of the visual radiations as they course from the lateral geniculate body to the visual cortex. It's not a circuit but rather a specific anatomical pathway for visual processing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The role of mammillary bodies in the Papez circuit is crucial for comprehending memory formation and emotional processing. The Papez circuit was one of the first circuits proposed to explain emotional processing in the brain, and while our understanding has evolved, it remains fundamental to understanding limbic system connectivity.

choices.text: Lower border of the upper rib
Upper border of the lower rib
Lower border of the lower rib

questions.text: What is the most preferred site for the needle insertion into the thoracic cavity for the pleural fluid removal? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Upper border of the lower rib

 

Explanation:

 

The most preferred site for needle insertion during a thoracentesis (removal of pleural fluid) is along the upper border of the lower rib within the intercostal space. This is because the neurovascular bundle (vein, artery, and nerve) runs along the lower border of each rib within the costal groove. Inserting the needle at the upper border of the lower rib minimizes the risk of damaging these vital structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lower border of the upper rib: Inserting the needle here would increase the risk of injuring the neurovascular bundle within the costal groove of the upper rib.

 

Option C. Lower border of the lower rib: This would also pose a high risk of damaging the neurovascular bundle.

 

Option D. Middle of the intercostal space: Inserting the needle here does not provide a safe margin away from the neurovascular structures and could still lead to injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For thoracentesis, always insert the needle at the upper border of the lower rib in the intercostal space to avoid damaging the neurovascular bundle located in the costal groove of the upper rib.

questions.text: Match the following in the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b

 

The image depicts the life cycle of the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which involves various hosts and vectors. Here's the correct matching:

 

  1. Accidental host (Human) - c: Humans are considered accidental hosts for JEV as they do not contribute to the ongoing transmission cycle.
  2. Amplifier (Pigs) - d: Pigs serve as amplifier hosts where the virus replicates to high levels, increasing the likelihood of mosquito transmission.
  3. Reservoir (Ardeid bird) - a: Birds, particularly Ardeid birds (herons and egrets), act as natural reservoirs of JEV.
  4. Vector (Culex) - b: Culex mosquitoes are the primary vectors that transmit JEV from reservoir hosts to amplifier hosts and to accidental hosts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Japanese encephalitis virus life cycle:

 

  • Humans are accidental hosts.
  • Pigs are amplifier hosts.
  • Ardeid birds are reservoir hosts.
  • Culex mosquitoes are the vectors responsible for transmission.

questions.text: All are features of Zika Fever except? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Petechial rash

 

Petechial rash is not a feature of Zika Virus. Though petechia may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC case definition of Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of Dengue fever while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease.

 

Petechial rash is not typically associated with Zika virus infection. It is more commonly associated with Dengue fever, where petechiae (small red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin) are a common feature.

 

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache and malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

 

The complications of Zika virus are:

 

  • Gullian Barre Syndrome
  • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guillain-Barre syndrome: Zika virus has been linked to Guillain-Barre syndrome, which can cause severe muscle weakness and even paralysis.

 

Option C. Fever with arthritis: Fever with arthritis or arthralgia is a common feature of Zika virus infection.

 

Option D. Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis (red eyes) is a frequent symptom of Zika virus infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zika fever typically presents with a maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, fever, and arthralgia, and it can be complicated by Guillain-Barre syndrome. Petechial rash is not a common feature and is more indicative of Dengue fever.

questions.text: What is the microscopy technique to produce high contrast image of transparent, live bacteria? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phase contrast microscopy

 

Phase-contrast microscopy (PCM) is an optical microscopy technique that converts phase shifts in light passing through a transparent specimen to brightness changes in the image. Phase shifts themselves are invisible, but become visible when shown as brightness variations.

 

Contrast is improved by using the difference in thickness or refractive index of structures within and around the cell. Difference in intensity of light is created as rays pass through varied refractive indices and produces contrast thus making the structures within the cells and its surroundings clearly visible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dark-field microscopy (also called dark-ground microscopy) describes microscopy methods, in both light and electron microscopy, which exclude the unscattered beam from the image. As a result, the field around the specimen (i.e., where there is no specimen to scatter the beam) is generally dark.

 

Option C. The electron microscope uses a beam of electrons and their wave-like characteristics to magnify an object's image, unlike the optical microscope that uses visible light to magnify images.

 

Option D. Polarized microscopy is used to visualize the intracellular structures using differences in birefringence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase contrast microscopy is the technique used to produce high contrast images of transparent, live bacteria by converting phase shifts into brightness changes.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge. A gram stain smear is made from the discharge sample and the following microscopic image is seen. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The clinic history along with microscopic image is suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Gram-negative, intracellular, cocci, usually seen in pairs (diplococci) with the adjacent sides flattened (typically kidney-shaped); (Looks like two coffee beans kissing).

 

In urethral discharge, it is predominately found within the polymorphs.

 

Gonococci do not contain capsules (meningococci do).

 

Virulence factors -

 

  • Pili: Pili mediate attachment to mucosal cell surfaces and also are antiphagocytic. Piliated gonococci are usually virulent, whereas nonpiliated strains are avirulent.
  • Lipooligosaccharides (LOS)
  • Outer membrane proteins and Opa proteins eg. Porin A: mediates invasion of the epithelial cells.
  • IgA protease hydrolyzes secretory IgA, which could otherwise block the attachment of Neisseria gonorrheae to the mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomonas: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan and not a gram-negative diplococcus.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis: Causes urethritis but is an obligate intracellular bacterium that does not show the gram-negative diplococcus morphology.

 

Option D. Gardnerella: Associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents as gram-variable coccobacilli, not gram-negative diplococci.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The presence of gram-negative, intracellular, kidney-shaped diplococci in urethral discharge is characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhea, a common causative agent of sexually transmitted infections resulting in urethritis.

questions.text: Receptive (Wernicke’s) aphasia is caused due to lesion in which of the following regions? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Superior temporal gyrus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Wernicke's area is located in Brodmann area 22
  • Found in the posterior portion of superior temporal gyrus
  • Critical for language comprehension
  • Lesions result in receptive (Wernicke's) aphasia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior frontal gyrus:

 

  • Location of Broca's area (Brodmann areas 44, 45)
  • Associated with speech production
  • Lesions cause expressive (Broca's) aphasia
  • Not involved in primary language comprehension

 

Option C. Angular gyrus:

 

  • Brodmann area 39
  • Role in reading comprehension and word processing
  • Links visual word forms to their meanings
  • Not the primary site for auditory language comprehension

 

Option D. Postcentral gyrus:

 

  • Primary somatosensory cortex (Brodmann areas 3,1,2)
  • Processes touch, temperature, and proprioception
  • No direct role in language processing
  • Located in parietal lobe

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding language areas in brain: 
    • Wernicke's area (BA 22) - comprehension
    • Location in dominant hemisphere (usually left)
    • Part of Wernicke-Geschwind model
    • Clinical features of different aphasias
  • Key differences between receptive and expressive language centers

questions.text: Which of the following disease has the highest mortality once clinically manifested? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rabies

 

Rabies is virtually 100% fatal once symptoms appear. It affects the central nervous system. It is a zoonotic disease, transmitted by a deep bite or scratch from an animal with rabies, which is, in 99% of the cases, a dog. It is preventable by a vaccine.

 

Nipah virus infection is fatal in 40 to 70 percent of cases.

 

Ebola case fatality rates have varied from 25% to 90% in past outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah: Nipah virus infection has a fatality rate of 40% to 70%. While severe, it is not as uniformly fatal as rabies once symptoms develop.

 

Option C. Ebola: Ebola virus disease has variable case fatality rates, ranging from 25% to 90% in different outbreaks. However, it is not as consistently fatal as rabies once symptoms manifest.

 

Option D. Zika: Zika virus infection is typically mild, and while it can cause severe complications such as microcephaly in newborns if contracted during pregnancy, it does not have a high mortality rate in symptomatic individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rabies has the highest mortality rate once clinical symptoms appear, making it virtually 100% fatal without immediate post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for typhoid fever in adults? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amikacin

 

Amikacin is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever as it is ineffective in clinical infections.

 

Amikacin is an aminoglycoside. Despite showing efficient in vitro killing of Salmonella, first- and second-generation cephalosporins, and aminoglycosides have proven to be ineffective in actual clinical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azithromycin: This macrolide antibiotic is commonly used for treating typhoid fever, especially in cases where fluoroquinolone resistance is present.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic, it has been a standard treatment for typhoid fever, though resistance to this class is increasing.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This third-generation cephalosporin is used to treat typhoid fever, particularly in cases of multidrug-resistant Salmonella typhi.

 

Educational Objective:


Amikacin is not effective in the treatment of typhoid fever, despite its efficacy in vitro against Salmonella.

choices.text: A – Apocrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Arrector pilorum, B – Apocrine sweat gland, C – Eccrine sweat gland, D – Sebaceous gland
A – Sebaceous gland, B – Eccrine sweat gland, C – Arrector pilorum, D – Apocrine sweat gland
A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the skin appendages labeled A to D in the given histological image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A – Eccrine sweat gland, B – Arrector pilorum, C – Sebaceous gland, D – Apocrine sweat gland

 

In the image provided, several distinct structures of the skin are labeled:

 

A (Eccrine sweat gland): Eccrine sweat glands are small, coiled glands located superficially in the dermis. They are responsible for temperature regulation through sweat secretion. In the image, A is identified as the eccrine sweat gland, which appears closer to the skin surface compared to the apocrine gland.

 

B (Arrector pilorum): This is a small muscle attached to the hair follicle known as the arrector pilorum. It is responsible for causing hair to stand up during cold or emotional stress, leading to goosebumps.

 

C (Sebaceous gland): These glands are associated with hair follicles and secrete sebum, an oily substance that lubricates the skin and hair. In the image, C is correctly identified as the sebaceous gland.

 

D (Apocrine sweat gland): Apocrine sweat glands are located deeper in the dermis or hypodermis and are associated with hair follicles. They produce a thicker, milky secretion that contributes to body odor when broken down by bacteria. D is correctly labeled as the apocrine sweat gland, which is found deeper compared to eccrine glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eccrine sweat glands are located closer to the skin surface, arrector pilorum is a small muscle connected to hair follicles, sebaceous glands produce sebum and are linked to hair follicles, while apocrine sweat glands are deeper and secrete a thicker fluid associated with hair follicles.

questions.text: A patient presents with fluent but nonsensical speech and has significant difficulty understanding spoken language, although their speech production remains intact. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Wernicke's area

 

Explanation:


The patient's symptoms are indicative of Wernicke's aphasia, which is characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired language comprehension. Wernicke's area (typically located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant hemisphere, usually the left) is essential for language comprehension. Damage to this area disrupts the ability to understand spoken language, leading to fluent but meaningless speech output.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Broca's area: Responsible for speech production and grammar. Damage here leads to expressive or non-fluent aphasia, where patients struggle to form words and construct sentences but generally understand language.
  • Option C. Heschl's gyrus: Located in the primary auditory cortex, it is involved in processing auditory information. Damage to this area would impair sound perception rather than language comprehension.
  • Option D. Striate area: Also known as the primary visual cortex, it is responsible for processing visual information. Damage to this area can lead to visual deficits but does not directly affect language functions.

 

Educational objective:


Damage to Wernicke's area results in receptive aphasia, where patients maintain fluent speech but have significant impairments in understanding language and producing meaningful communication.

questions.text:
Which of the following vaccinations are specifically recommended during pregnancy according to standard guidelines? [Twisted PYQ]

  1. Influenza (inactivated)
  2. Tdap
  3. Live attenuated vaccines
  4. HPV
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2

 

Pregnant women should receive:

  • Inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV) during any trimester of pregnancy to protect both mother and developing fetus
  • Tdap vaccine during each pregnancy, optimally between 27-36 weeks gestation, to provide passive antibody protection to the infant

 

Other Options:

 

Options (3, 4):

  • Live attenuated vaccines (like MMR, varicella) are contraindicated during pregnancy due to theoretical risk to the fetus
  • HPV vaccination should be delayed until after pregnancy
  • Adding these options makes these answer choices incorrect

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Only inactivated or toxoid vaccines are safe during pregnancy
  • Timing of Tdap is crucial for maternal antibody transfer
  • Live vaccines pose theoretical risks to fetus

 

Pregnancy is temporary contraindication for certain vaccines

questions.text: Which structure develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ductus arteriosus

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery plays a crucial role in embryonic development, particularly in forming structures related to the circulatory system. On the left side, the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery develops into the ductus arteriosus, a vital fetal blood vessel that allows blood to bypass the lungs, which are not yet functional before birth. After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arch of aorta: The arch of the aorta is primarily derived from the left 4th pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Option C. Subclavian artery: The right subclavian artery is derived from the right 4th pharyngeal arch artery and other structures, while the left subclavian artery arises from the left 7th intersegmental artery.

 

Option D. Common carotid artery: The common carotid artery primarily arises from the 3rd pharyngeal arch artery, not the 6th.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus, a critical structure in fetal circulation, develops from the distal part of the 6th pharyngeal arch artery on the left side.

questions.text: Marked structure is derived from the?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endocardial cushions

 

Explanation:

 

The interventricular septum's membranous portion is the indicated structure. It comes from the endocardial cushions.

 

 

  • Endocardial cushions are soft tissue masses that protrude in the atrioventricular and conotruncal regions.
    • Atrioventricular cushions are derived from overlying endocardial cells.
    • The conotruncal cushions are derived from the neural crest cells.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Septum primum: The septum primum is involved in the development of the atrial septum, not the interventricular septum. It forms a temporary structure in the embryonic heart that helps separate the atria.

 

Option C. Left venous valve: The left venous valve is not directly involved in the formation of the interventricular septum. It is a structure found within the embryonic heart that helps direct oxygenated blood from the left atrium into the left ventricle.

 

Option D. Bulbous venosus: The bulbous venosus is an embryonic structure that contributes to the formation of the smooth part of the right ventricle. It is not associated with the development of the interventricular septum.

 

 

Cardiac abnormalities, such as ASs, VSDs, and anomalies affecting the major arteries, can be caused by errors in the creation of the endocardial cushion (transposition of the great vessels, common truncus arterious, and tetralogy of Fallot).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endocardial cushions contribute to the formation of:

 

  1. Atrial septa
  2. Ventricular septa (membranous portion)
  3. Atrioventricular canals
  4. Atrioventricular valves

 

The membranous portion of the interventricular septum develops from the endocardial cushions.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: A patient suspected of having acute brucellosis had a serum sample sent for a standard agglutination test. The test was strongly positive initially but became negative after serial dilutions of the serum sample. Which of the following best explains this observation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Post-zone phenomenon

 

The initial positive test followed by negative results after dilution is explained by the post-zone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test mainly identifies IgM antibodies and is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Post-zone phenomenon occurs when there is an excess of antigen relative to antibodies, leading to initial visible agglutination. When the sample is diluted, the optimal antigen-antibody ratio is disrupted, resulting in negative results. This is because there are insufficient antibodies to form visible cross-links between antigens.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies.

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system (weak/absent precipitation initially, becomes positive on dilution)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to excess antigen (positive initially, becomes negative on dilution)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These antibodies lack the ability to cause agglutination and wouldn't explain the pattern of initial positive followed by negative results.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This process isn't relevant to the pattern observed and primarily affects complement-dependent reactions.

 

Option C. Prozone phenomenon: This occurs with excess antibodies and shows the opposite pattern - negative initially, becoming positive on dilution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The post-zone phenomenon demonstrates how excess antigen can affect serological testing, producing initially positive results that become negative upon dilution. This emphasizes the importance of understanding antigen-antibody ratios in diagnostic testing and interpretation of serological results.

choices.text: Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment
IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis
Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris

questions.text: A woman with recurrent diarrhea is prescribed a broad-spectrum antibiotic. Which of the following is not true regarding Clostridium difficile infection?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IgM assay is used to confirm the diagnosis

 

  • IgM assay cannot be used to confirm a diagnosis of Clostridium difficile infection. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin in stool samples.
  • C. difficile, a gram-positive anaerobic bacillus, causes Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection (CDI) after ingestion of spores of the organism.
  • The more severe form of the condition is known as pseudomembranous colitis (PMC). It is most commonly associated with prolonged antimicrobial use which interferes with the commensal colonic microflora. The most commonly implicated antibiotics are cephalosporins, ampicillin, and clindamycin.
  • The spores are spread by contact with the feces of affected individuals or asymptomatic carriers.
  • The spores germinate in the small intestine and produce two toxins - toxin A (enterotoxin) and toxin B (cytotoxin). These interfere with the epithelial-cell barrier function and result in diarrhea and pseudomembrane formation.
  • The pseudomembranes appear as small whitish-yellow plaques initially which later coalesce to involve the entire colon wall. It contains necrotic leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris. The anamnestic IgG response determines which patients develop the disease or remain asymptomatic.
  • Symptoms include diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain. The diagnosis is based on a combination of clinical criteria and detection of toxin  A Or Toxin B or the organism in stool samples. The mere presence of bacteria in stool does not itend that the patient has the disease as clostridoides difficile is a commensal in the gut. Onlly confirmed toxin detection suggests significant infection with clostridoides difficile  This can be done by nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT methods such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or by culture. 
  • Discontinuation of any ongoing antimicrobials and hydration are general measures that are recommended. Oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin is the first-line treatment. Oral metronidazole can be used when these are not available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral fidaxomicin is used for treatment: This is true; fidaxomicin is a first-line treatment for C. difficile infection, especially in cases of recurrence.

 

Option B. It is toxin mediated: True; the clinical manifestations of CDI are due to the effects of toxins A and B.

 

Option D. Pseudomembrane consists of leukocytes, fibrin, and cellular debris: Also true, this describes the characteristic appearance of the pseudomembrane seen in pseudomembranous colitis, a severe form of CDI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile infection is diagnosed primarily through the detection of toxins rather than IgM assays is crucial for appropriate management. This recognition guides the effective use of specific treatments such as oral fidaxomicin or vancomycin, aimed at countering the effects of these toxins and managing the symptoms of the infection.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presented with complaints of diarrhea and foul-smelling stool. His stool microscopy did not show any ova or eggs, but there was the presence of motile 200 μm larva. Identify the organism. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The Ans.  is Strongyloides stercoralis because this organism is known for producing motile larvae rather than eggs in the stool, which aligns with the findings in this patient. Strongyloides stercoralis is unique among the listed options in that it is ovoviviparous: it produces eggs that hatch into larvae inside the host. This explains why motile larvae, rather than eggs or ova, are observed in stool microscopy.

 

This characteristic is crucial for distinguishing Strongyloides from other helminths, particularly in immunocompromised patients like those with HIV, where the infection can become disseminated and more severe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma duodenale: This organism typically shows eggs, not larvae, in stool samples. It is a type of hookworm, and its diagnostic stage involves eggs rather than motile larvae.

 

Option B. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris is diagnosed by finding eggs in the stool, not larvae. It is a large roundworm whose diagnostic stage in stool is the presence of characteristic eggs.

 

Option C. Schistosoma mansoni: Schistosoma species are identified by the presence of characteristic eggs in stool or urine, depending on the species. Motile larvae are not seen in stool samples for Schistosoma infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Strongyloides stercoralis is diagnosed by the presence of motile larvae in stool, distinguishing it from other helminths that typically show eggs in stool samples.

questions.text: Identify the organism shown below, which causes effacement and attachment of intestinal cells? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EPEC

 

Attachment and effacement lesions on intestinal cells are caused by enteropathogenic Escherichia coli (EPEC).

 

EPEC adheres to the mucosal cells of the small bowel and causes loss of microvilli (effacement). This leads to the formation of filamentous actin pedestals or cuplike structures and occasionally may cause entry of the EPEC into the mucosal cells.

 

Pathogenicity requires the presence of two important factors:

 

  • Bundle-forming pilus encoded by plasmid containing EPEC adherence factor (EAF).
  • Chromosomal locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETEC: ETEC is known for causing watery diarrhea via enterotoxins but does not cause the attachment and effacement lesions seen with EPEC.

 

Option B. EIEC: EIEC causes invasive disease and dysentery by invading and destroying epithelial cells, but it does not cause attachment and effacement lesions.

 

Option D. EHEC: EHEC causes hemorrhagic colitis and can lead to hemolytic-uremic syndrome through the production of Shiga toxin, but it does not cause the effacement and attachment of intestinal cells as EPEC does.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following methods would be most appropriate for determining if a patient has recently recovered from a viral infection? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ELISA (IgG)

 

ELISA testing for virus-specific IgG antibodies is the most appropriate method to determine recent recovery from viral infection. IgG antibodies typically develop during the course of infection and remain elevated after recovery, serving as indicators of past infection or immunity. ELISA can quantitatively measure these specific antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Real-time PCR: While excellent for measuring active viral load, PCR detects viral genetic material and would likely be negative in a recently recovered patient as the virus has been cleared.

 

Option C. Western blot: Though it can detect specific proteins including antibodies, it's more complex, time-consuming, and qualitative compared to ELISA. It's typically used as a confirmatory test rather than primary screening.

 

Option D. Immunoelectrophoresis: This method separates proteins based on their electrical charge and size but lacks the specificity needed to accurately measure virus-specific antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ELISA is optimal for detecting post-infection antibodies · Real-time PCR measures active viral presence 
  • Western blot confirms specific protein presence · Immunoelectrophoresis separates proteins but lacks specificity for viral antibody detection

questions.text: Which among the following is the most specific disease caused by Streptococcus agalactiae?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neonatal sepsis

 

Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), is a significant cause of neonatal infections. It is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis globally. The bacteria exhibit beta-hemolysis on blood agar, characterized by complete lysis of red blood cells around the colonies, forming a clear zone. This hemolytic property helps in identifying and differentiating it from other types of Streptococci. GBS is biochemically identified as hippurate hydrolysis positive and CAMP test positive, both of which are unique to this bacterium. These tests confirm its identity and help in diagnosing infections caused by it.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Infective endocarditis: Although Streptococcus agalactiae can occasionally cause infective endocarditis, it is not the most specific or common disease caused by this bacterium. Infective endocarditis is more commonly associated with other Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus viridans.

 

Option C. Dental caries: Dental caries are typically associated with Streptococcus mutans, not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. mutans plays a primary role in the development of tooth decay due to its ability to ferment sugars into acids, which demineralize the dental enamel.

 

Option D. Pharyngitis with or without tonsillitis: Pharyngitis, commonly known as strep throat, is primarily caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), not Streptococcus agalactiae. S. pyogenes is known for causing various suppurative and non-suppurative infections, including pharyngitis, rheumatic fever, and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B Streptococcus) is the most common cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Great cardiac vein

 

The marked structure in the provided image is the great cardiac vein. The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD). This vein collects blood from the anterior surfaces of both ventricles and drains into the coronary sinus.

 

The great cardiac vein is the largest of the veins draining the heart muscle (myocardium), and it is crucial in returning deoxygenated blood from the myocardium to the coronary sinus and eventually into the right atrium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cardiac vein: These veins drain directly into the right atrium and do not run in the anterior interventricular sulcus. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

 

Option C. Middle cardiac vein: This vein runs in the posterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the posterior interventricular artery. It is not located in the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Small cardiac vein: This vein is located on the right side of the heart and accompanies the right coronary artery. It is not associated with the anterior interventricular sulcus, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular sulcus with the anterior interventricular artery and is crucial for draining blood from the anterior aspects of the heart.

questions.text: Which congenital deformity is shown in the image? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anencephaly, craniorachischisis

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a congenital deformity characterized by the absence of the cranial vault (anencephaly) and the exposure of the entire spinal cord due to the non-fusion of the neural tube (craniorachischisis).

  • Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This occurs due to the failure of the anterior neuropore to close during embryonic development.
  • Craniorachischisis involves the failure of closure of both the anterior and posterior neuropores, leading to the exposure of the brain and spinal cord. The entire neural tube remains open, resulting in severe defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Anencephaly: This option only accounts for the absence of the cranial vault but does not include the exposed spinal cord.

 

Option C.  Meningomyelocele, anencephaly: Meningomyelocele refers to a form of spina bifida where the spinal cord and meninges protrude through a defect in the spine. While the image does show an exposed spinal cord, it is not a localized defect as seen in meningomyelocele.

 

Option D.  Spina bifida occulta, anencephaly: Spina bifida occulta is a mild form of spina bifida where the vertebral arches fail to fuse but without protrusion of the spinal contents. The image shows a more severe defect.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly with craniorachischisis involves the non-closure of the neural tube, resulting in the absence of the cranial vault and exposure of the spinal cord along its entire length.

questions.text: TB test done only on whole blood sample is:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interferon gamma release assay

 

TB test done on a whole blood sample is the interferon-gamma release assay. It has been used for the diagnosis of latent tuberculosis in patients with HIV (who frequently have a negative Mantoux test).

 

Interferon-gamma release assays include:

 

  • QuantiFERON-TB Gold
  • T-SPOT.TB

 

QuantiFERON-TB Gold quantitates the amount of IN- produced by CD4+ T cells in response to the antigens from Mycobacterium tuberculosis. QuantiFERON-TB Gold Plus (QFT- Plus) is an improved version of the QuantiFERON-TB Gold test. QuantiFERON-TB Gold detects only TB-specific CD4+ responses. However, QuantiFeron-TB Gold Plus detects both CD8+ and CD4+ T-cell responses to TB-specific antigens.

 

T-SPOT.TB determines the total number of individual effector T cells expressing IFN-v.

 

The TrueNat TB test is a new molecular test that can diagnose TB in one hour as well as test for rifampicin resistance. This test uses a sputum sample taken from the patient. Only about 0.5 ml of the sample is required. Gene Xpert is also a molecular method of testing that cannot use blood as a sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TrueNat TB: Incorrect, as this molecular test diagnoses TB and tests for rifampicin resistance using a sputum sample, not whole blood.

 

Option B. Gene Xpert: Incorrect, this is another molecular test that identifies TB and resistance to rifampicin but also uses sputum samples rather than whole blood.

 

Option D. All of the above: Incorrect, as only the interferon gamma release assay is designed to be used with whole blood samples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Interferon gamma release assay is a valuable tool for diagnosing latent TB, particularly suitable for patients who may not be effectively diagnosed through traditional skin tests, offering a sensitive and specific method that utilizes whole blood to detect an immune response to TB antigens.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in a child presenting with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Toxoplasma

 

The presentation of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is highly indicative of congenital toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii, which can infect the fetus during pregnancy if the mother acquires the infection. The classic triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes:

 

  1. Chorioretinitis
  2. Hydrocephalus
  3. Diffuse parenchymal calcifications

 

These parenchymal calcifications are distributed throughout the brain tissue, which is a key distinguishing feature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Zika virus: Zika virus infections are primarily associated with microcephaly, calcifications in both the gray and white matter, and other severe brain malformations, not specifically with parenchymal calcifications along with hydrocephalus and chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Rubella: Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to multiple defects, including hearing loss, heart defects, and cataracts. However, it is not typically associated with the triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications.

 

Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Congenital CMV infection is commonly associated with periventricular calcifications rather than diffuse parenchymal calcifications. This means calcifications are found around the ventricles of the brain rather than throughout the parenchyma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and parenchymal calcifications is characteristic of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: Patients with which of the following conditions are more susceptible to infections caused by catalase-positive organisms:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) is an immunodeficiency disorder that makes patients particularly susceptible to infections by catalase-positive organisms. This condition arises from a defect in the NADPH oxidase complex in phagocytes, which is crucial for the production of reactive oxygen species used to kill ingested pathogens.

 

Key points about CGD:

 

  • Pathophysiology: In CGD, phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils and macrophages) are unable to produce reactive oxygen species due to a defective NADPH oxidase enzyme. This impairs the killing of certain bacteria and fungi.
  • Catalase-positive organisms: These organisms can neutralize hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), a reactive oxygen species that the host cells might produce. Catalase-positive bacteria include Staphylococcus aureus, Serratia marcescens, Aspergillus species, Nocardia, and Pseudomonas.
  • Recurrent Infections: Patients with CGD frequently suffer from recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly with catalase-positive organisms due to their inability to effectively kill these pathogens.

 

Other Options:
